case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX, A.P. vs HYDERABAD STONE DEPOT AND OTHERS
appellant: Commissioner of Income Tax, Andhra Pradesh

accussed_details.name: Subash Keswarkar
accussed_details.designation: Partner (Minor admitted to benefits of partnership)

complaint_summary: The Income Tax Officer refused registration of the firm under Section 26A of the Income Tax Act, citing lack of clarity in the partnership deed regarding the sharing of losses among major partners.
investigation_summary: The Income Tax Officer initially treated the firm as unregistered, later reopened the assessment and treated it as registered. Subsequent appeals led to the refusal of registration based on alleged defects in the partnership deed.
judgment_summary: The Full Bench held that the partnership deed specified the shares of major partners in losses and satisfied the requirements of Section 26A of the Income Tax Act. The Tribunal was justified in granting registration despite minor defects in the application.
Decision_or_verdict: Registration of the firm allowed for the assessment year 1959-60.
result: Question reframed and answered in the negative
legal_arguments: Section 26A requires specification of individual shares in profit and loss.
Minor admitted to benefits of partnership does not affect registration.
Technical defects in the application should not lead to refusal of registration.
citations: Addepally Nageswara Rao v. Commissioner of Income Tax [1971] 79 ITR 306 (AP)
Commissioner of Income Tax v. Mandyala Govindu & Co [1971] 82 ITR 926 (AP)
Khummaji Milapchand & Co. v. Commissioner of Income Tax [1973] 91 ITR 333 (AP)
key_issues: Whether the partnership deed sufficiently specifies the shares of major partners in losses.
Whether technical defects in the registration application justify refusal of registration.

income_tax_officer_actions: Initial assessment treating firm as unregistered
Reopened assessment treating firm as registered
Refusal to register firm under Section 26A

tribunal_decision.loss_sharing: Academic interest due to no loss during assessment year

full_bench_decision.interpretation_of_deed: Shares of major partners in losses specified

legal_terms.Section 26A: Provision for registration of firms under the Income Tax Act.

words_and_phrases.specifying: Mentioning, describing, or defining in detail.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the refusal of registration of a partnership firm under Section 26A of the Income Tax Act due to alleged defects in the partnership deed and application. The Full Bench clarified that the deed sufficiently specifies the shares of major partners in losses and technical defects in the application should not lead to refusal. The firm was granted registration for the assessment year 1959-60.
